newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH BANKS' CORPORATE SECTOR LOANS FALL IN AUG.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH BANKS' CORPORATE SECTOR LOANS FALL IN AUG.

text.p: Finnish banks' new markka credits to the corporate sector fell to 2.01 billion markka in August from 2.06 billion in July, the Bank of Finland said in its monthly financial markets review 10/96 received on Friday.
The amount of new markka credits to the corporatre sector granted in August was the lowest in any month since September 1995, the central bank said.

The stock of corporate sector markka credits fell to 82.86 billion markka by end-August from 83.12 billion a month earlier. At end-August 1995, the stock was 82.33 billion markka, and at end-1995, it was 78.60 billion, the Bank of Finland said.

The average rate of interest on banks' new markka loans to the corporate sector fell to 5.52 percent in August from 5.72 percent in July. The average rate of interest on the stock of these loans fell to 5.55 percent in August from 5.61 percent in July.
The stock of banks' total markka lending to the public turned back into a rise in August, to 269.3 billion markka, after a slight fall in July to 268.4 billion.
The average rate of interest on the stock of total markka lending to the public fell to 6.41 percent in August from 6.47 percent in July, the Bank of Finland said.

New markka credits granted to households rose to 3.5 billion markka in August from 3.4 billion in July and the average rate of interest on these new markka loans fell to 6.76 percent from 6.91 percent.

The stock of households' markka credits rose to 153.3 billion markka at end-August from 152.7 billion and the average rate of interest on the stock fell to 7.09 percent from 7.14 percent, the central bank said.
